DOC.TEXT: U.S. industry should enjoy its eighth consecutive year of rising sales in 1990 but growth will be sluggish, with automaking and construction particularly hard hit, the government said. In its annual industrial outlook, the Commerce Department predicted Thursday that 150 of 193 manufacturing industries it surveyed would enjoy rising sales in the coming year. But the other one-fourth of manufacturing industries will experience either no sales increase or a decline in sales, the department predicted.

The United States enters the 1990s facing tough decisions needed to erase policy mistakes in the last decade that threaten its global economic leadership, a congressional study concluded. The study, prepared by the staff of the Joint Economic Committee and released Thursday, said the No. 1 economic problem facing the country was the federal budget deficit. ``We will not solve our most pressing economic problems unless we reduce the deficit,'' the study said.

The recent weather-related jump in energy and wholesale food prices should have a minimal impact on interest rates barring severe crop or oil shortages, but frigid temperatures in coming months could chill investors' inflation outlook, economists said. A record-setting cold snap in the past week has heavily damaged fruit and vegetable crops in such major growing areas as Florida and Texas and sent heating oil prices soaring in many parts of the country. Oil futures prices, which had risen sharply in recent days, dropped Thursday amid profit-taking and higher deposit requirements imposed by the New York Mercantile Exchange.

Eastern Airlines said it will cut 600 jobs and temporarily trim salaries for about 10,000 workers as the retrenching carrier prepares to sell its Latin American routes and shrink its home base. The downsizing, announced Thursday, is part of Eastern's plan for reorganization in the wake of the strike that idled the carrier for several months early this year. The move reflects Eastern's intention to return to its original reorganization plan of cutting its pre-strike operations by a third. In August, Eastern said it decided to pare operations by only 10 percent.

General Motors Corp. will cut about 3,200 production jobs at three plants in February and March because of slow auto sales, the nation's biggest automaker said in another indication of the industry's severe slump. The cuts, announced Thursday, are in addition to temporary shutdowns announced last week by GM, Ford Motor Co. and Chrysler Corp. and mark the second major production cuts announced by GM in as many weeks.

Three heirs to the Campbell Soup Co. fortune put their 17 percent stake up for sale and urged that the entire food-products company be sold, intensifying a rift between members of the founding family. The group, comprised of three nieces of Campbell's late Chairman John T. Dorrance Jr. and their husbands, said in a Securities and Exchange Commission filing that it would seek ``a price per share significantly in excess of current market value.'' The group also said Thursday it would encourage Campbell's board of directors to do the same and consider ousting members who opposed a sale.

Florida orange growers and northern heating-oil users may curse the cold, but the weather has been a blessing to commodity speculators who have profited from skyrocketing futures prices of the two products. Speculative trader George Booth estimated Thursday his customers will make $700,000 to $1 million from the Florida freeze. The Norwood Hyacinth Fund, a public futures fund managed by Dunn Capital Management Inc. in Stuart, Fla., tallied profits of $383,000 in the heating-oil futures market from Nov. 22 through Wednesday.

The United States has asked Japan to help rebuild Panama's shattered economy and dispatched a team of experts to assess the costs of repairing the devastation from last week's military invasion, officials said. In addition, representatives from the Treasury, State and Commerce departments have begun deliberations on long-term plans to repair the damage wrought by two years of U.S. economic warfare against former Panamanian ruler Manuel Antonio Noriega.

With air travel expected to slow during the winter months, big airlines are aiming to stimulate traffic by cutting fares as much as 30 percent in selected markets. The fare reductions, in effect through early March, only apply to around 10 percent of the airlines' route networks _ but they involve densely traveled routes.

Stock prices inched up Thursday, continuing their tentative yearend rally. The Dow Jones average of 30 industrials rose 7.90 points to 2,732.30. The dollar finished sharply higher in domestic trading after putting in a mixed performance overseas. Gold prices fell. Bond prices advanced moderately. Orange juice futures prices added to their freeze-driven gains; near-month heating oil futures closed lower for the first time in nine days; precious metals retreated; grains and soybeans advanced; and livestock and meat futures were mixed.
